bibl.title: 1820 Apr. 8 [to] James Winchester, Cragfont, Tennessee / Jno. Charles Cassedy
bibl.author: Cassedy, Jno. Charles
bibl.note: This is a letter from Charles Cassedy to General James Winchester, dated April 8, 1820. Cassedy is requesting that Winchester send him a horse which he will use to visit him. The visit is on the request of Captain Eastland. He also criticizes General Andrew Jackson's advisors.

projectDesc.p: Created for the University of Tennessee Digital Library

editorialDecl.p: Quotation marks retained as data except inside q tags
Errors in transcription of the printed text controlled with X-Metal 2.1 spell-checker; text has also been thoroughly proofread.
Corrections and normalization represented by editorial tags.
Catchwords and directional notes such as "turn page over" have been omitted.

refsDecl.p: ID attributes provided for only those pages, chapters, or illustrations toward which a reference or figure points.

div1.p: I wish you to send down for me a horse &c with which I will come up. Capt Eastland will accompany me. He wishes to see us together His reasons are best known to himself; but no doubt he will explain them to your satisfaction. Let the horse be left at Capt Jno Allens cotton Factory.
I would send you, but am not at liberty, having borrowed the papers, the Report of Mr Storns on the subject of the Seminole war. It is very suave _ and very masterly; but unjust.
Gen Jackson is cursed with advisors whoes abilities are utterly incompetent to render his character justice; and with supporters who have no conception of the era to which his fame ought to live.

closer.salute:
with respect and
the most sincere friendship
I am Dr Sir your &c
